author: David Claughton
title: Emergency service cranks up campaign to stop people driving into floodwater
text:
Map: Sydney 2000 
Emergency services are frustrated by people making bad decisions when faced with floodwater, as recent studies on flood deaths show young men and children are the most at-risk of dying. 
Almost 80 per cent of flood-related deaths are male, and almost half are children or young adults under 29 years old. 
Overall, the number of flood deaths is trending down , but people are still ignoring warnings to stay away from floodwater. 
Peter, a farmer who features in a new campaign, battled floods to save his stock and almost lost his son as they attempted to move frightened dairy cattle out of a corner of a paddock where they were trapped by rising water. 
His son disappeared momentarily but resurfaced and scrambled to safety. 
Shortly afterwards, strong winds whipped up waves on their property that almost drowned Peter himself. 
"We had a big southerly blowing with the rain, which caused a very big wave [and] that's when I got into trouble," he said. 
"It was really, really frightening, when the water is in your lungs and you know you're in trouble." 
Peter decided to tell his story to raise awareness of the risks, and it has become part of a social media campaign launched by the State Emergency Service in New South Wales. Planning needed to prevent animals getting trapped 
The SES' David King said better planning for floods on farm could reduce the risks. 
Livestock often get trapped in the corner of a paddock because there is not a gate, or it has not been opened ahead of the flood. 
"Knowing there's a flood coming, either open gates or move your stock," Mr King said. 
"Animals are fairly resilient. They can swim and move to higher ground." People ignore risks of floodwater 
Mr King has been rescuing people and animals from floods for three decades. 
He said flood rescues were among the most dangerous things the SES did, and he wanted young men especially to avoid going into floodwater. External Link: Peter drove into flood water to impress his girlfriend 
"They have this sense they are bomb-proof," he said. 
"They see a bit of water on the road and they think, 'This'll be fun, we'll make a few waves, spray a bit of water around' and they don't realise that road has been washed away." 
Research shows people often underestimate the strength and depth of the water, and drivers cannot tell what is under the surface. 
Twilight is an especially dangerous time because people are prepared to take risks to get home, and the majority of deaths happen in minor and moderate flood events because people underestimate the risk. 
Mr King said people, especially children, should stay out of floodwater because it was toxic. 
"As soon as we get flooding we're getting septic tanks and sewage treatment plants overloading, and here are these kids swimming around in this biological porridge of faecal matter and they don't realise it," he said. 
The campaign includes stories by survivors, including a mother who crossed a flooded river based on pressure from her passengers, a mother who turned around based on fear of putting the lives her children at risk, and a 4WD enthusiast and his experience crossing creeks and rivers.
